# Introduction


## Definition :
*   Lymph node tuberculosis (LNTB, also called TB lymphadenitis) refers to *M. tuberculosis* infection of the lymph nodes.
*   As sole manifestation of TB, or alongside pulmonary or miliary TB.
*   Chest radiograph may show findings in nearly 27.7% of LN TB patients.
*   Commonest form of extrapulmonary mycobacterial disease (35% of EPTB) - TB lymph node.

---

## Site

MC: **cervical adenopathy** is most common
(45-75% cases), but inguinal, axillary,
mesenteric and mediastinal involvement
Most common cause of mycobacterial
lymphadenitis caused by- **Mycobacterium tuberculosis [Mtb]** and can also occur due
to **nontuberculous mycobacteria [NTM]**

# Epidemiology

The peak age of onset in developed countries has shifted from childhood to ages 20 to 40 years.

In developing countries where TB is endemic, extrapulmonary TB occurs in up to 60 percent of HIV-infected patients with TB

Extrapulmonary TB cases (including tuberculous lymphadenitis) usually occur among patients with HIV at CD4 counts <300 cells/microL (usually below 100 cells/microL)

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIR FACI EDARM

<!-- Page 6 -->



# Pathogenesis



## Modes of entry of bacilli



### Via respiratory tract
*   haematogenous and lymphatic dissemination.
*   Hilar and mediastinal LN involved initially



### Via tonsils
*   Spreads via the lymphatics to the draining cervical lymph nodes.
    *   **Waldeyer's Tonsillar Ring**
        *   Lateral pharyngeal band
        *   Adenoids
        *   Tubal Tonsil
        *   Nodules on posterior pharyngeal wall
        *   Palatine Tonsil
        *   Lingual Tonsil



### Via swallowing
*   occur via swallowing of sputum or milk infected with *M. tuberculosis*/*M. bovis*

---

<!-- Page 7 -->



# Pathogenesis ; events

Entry & mutliplication $\rightarrow$ Onset of delayed hypersensitivity (DHR) $\rightarrow$ Marked hyperaemia, necrosis and caseation $\rightarrow$ Inflammation, progressive swelling and matting

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 8 -->



# Pathogenesis : events

*   **Adhesion to the adjacent skin, induration and purplish discoloration**
*   **Centre of the enlarging gland becomes soft and caseous material**
*   **Rupture into surrounding tissue or through the skin with sinus formation**

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 9 -->



# Jones and Campbell classification

*   **Stage 1-** Enlarged, firm, mobile, discrete nodes showing non-specific reactive hyperplasia (Handwritten: E-FMD)
*   **Stage 2-** Larger rubbery nodes fixed to surrounding tissue owing to periadenitis (Handwritten: OO, wavy line)
*   **Stage 3-** Central softening due to caseation necrosis and abscess formation ? Cold abscess
    *   Cold abscess (not warm) (Handwritten: d/t low grade inflammation)
*   **Stage 4-** Abscess (rupture) through deep fascia under skin → Collar-stud abscess formation
*   **Stage 5-** discharging Sinus tract formation

---

**Diagram Stages:**

*   **Stage 1:** Lymphadenitis
*   **Stage 2:** Matting
*   **Stage 3:** Cold abscess (Deep to deep fascia)
*   **Stage 4:** Collar stud abscess (Rupture through deep fascia, the skin, cross-fluctuant, adherent to skin)
*   **Stage 5:** Sinus formation

# Symptoms

*   chronic non-tender lymphadenopathy in a young adult with
    fever
*   most commonly in the cervical region
*   Cough may be a prominent symptom in patients with
    mediastinal lymphadenopathy

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP
FACI EDARM

<!-- Page 12 -->



# Examination

*   Palpable lymphadenopathy - varying size, number and consistency
*   Size of lymph node: Significant if >2 cm diameter in the inguinal region and >1 cm in other regions ⭐
*   Generalized (>3 groups) - (DID) HIV/NHL/TB/Infectious Mononucleosis/SLE. ✔️✔️✔️✔️✔️
*   Lymph nodes - discrete or matted, firm or cystic inconsistency if necrosis and abscess formation ✔️
*   Matted lymph node: Matted lymph nodes are described as a group of nodes that are conglomerated. ✔️ ⭕⭕ 〰️〰️
*   Not tender unless secondary bacterial infection. ✔️

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB, FIP, FADI, EDARU

---

<!-- Page 13 -->



# Differential Diagnosis of Lymphadenopathy

*   **Infectious**
    *   Mycobacterium tuberculosis
    *   NTM
    *   Bacterial: sinusitis, otitis externa, cellulitis, abscess, tonsillitis, pharyngitis
    *   Viral: EBV, CMV, HIV
    *   Others: fungal, parasitological
*   Sarcoidosis
*   SLE
*   Castleman disease
*   Histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis (Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease)
*   Drugs
*   **Neoplasms**
    *   Primary hematologic malignancy: HL, NHL
    *   Melanoma, SCC skin cancers
    *   Solid-organ cancer metastatic
*   Miscellaneous conditions

# WHAT TESTS ?



## ALL
*   CXR ✔
*   HIV Testing ✔
*   FNAC \*



### Superficial lymphadenopathy sample
*   **Cytopathology** ✔ (by pathologist)
*   **CBNAAT** (GeneXpert MTB/RIF) ✔
*   **AFB** ✔
*   **Culture** (MGIT/LJ media) wherever possible ✔ (microbiology)



## Selected pts
*   USG ✔
*   CT chest & abdomen
*   Excision biopsy \*: IF FNAC has been inconclusive, or where malignancy is suspected.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB (PULMONARY MEDICINE)

# Sampling & Investigations

-   FNA: Direct / Usg guided
-   Limitations of FNA : <mark style="background-color: #D4EDDA;">Limited sample amount</mark>
    a.  Tissue morphology might be distorted in immunodeficiency i.e. HIV

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 16 -->



# Sampling & Investigations- Biopsy

(When)
*   FNA is not diagnostic in the setting of strong clinical suspicion of TB or alternate diagnosis is suspected. => Biopsy
*   Excisional biopsy >> incisional biopsy (TBEB [Trans Bronchial cryo Biopsy])
*   Mediastinal lymph node biopsy - mediastinoscopy/VATS

(Handwritten notes around "Biopsy" title):
(HPE)
-> CBNAAT
-> AFB
-> culture

**Merits:**
*   Highest diagnostic yield / adequacy of sample

**Limitations:**
*   Requires experience
*   Local complications like infection, sinus tract formation

DR. BHARATH RATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARU

<!-- Page 17 -->

FNAC > Biopsy
(NAAT +ve)

Note: Finding of a caseating granuloma on histopathology with constitutional symptoms is highly suggestive of tuberculosis, ATT may be initiated in such cases even in absence of microbiological evidence

# Role of radiological imaging in TBLN

*   **USG**: Tuberculous nodes tend to be hypoechoic, round, without echogenic hilus and tend to show intranodal cystic necrosis, nodal matting, and adjacent soft-tissue oedema.
*   **EBUS**: EBUS-TBNA in whom mediastinal TB is suspected
    *   *p. D/t tuberculous inflammation*
*   **CT**: Lymph nodes showing peripheral enhancement with hypodense centres, secondary to caseous and/or liquefactive necrosis. Conglomerate lymph node masses with areas of necrosis secondary to perinodal inflammation.
*   **MRI**: follow-up cases of mediastinal tuberculosis : mostly hyperintense on T2-weighted images.
*   During anti-TB treatment, some bacillus-negative tuberculomas do not decrease in size and may even increase, making it difficult for the physician to decide whether to modify treatment.
*   18F-FDG PET/CT imaging may help, as the changes in glycolytic activity within the inflammatory lesion, measured by 18F-FDG uptake, correlate well with the clinical markers of response
    *   *\[X No Metabolic Activity -> It can be dropped]*

Dr. Bharath Kadi MD DNB FIR FACI EDARM
39

---

<!-- Page 19 -->



# CT

CT provides knowledge of the **site, extent and status** of the affected lymph node

“**RIM SIGN**” that consists of a hypodense centres, representing caseous necrosis, surrounded by a peripheral enhancing rim due to granulomatous inflammatory tissue. (not pathognomonic)

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 20 -->

# Treatment

LNTB primarily requires medical management, adjunct surgical excision is generally associated with worse outcomes. 6 - ⑨ months
Six months ATT standard first-line regimen is recommended for peripheral lymph node TB

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB, FIP FACI EDARW

---

<!-- Page 22 -->



# Assess Response To Treatment At 3- 4 Months



## Response to therapy at 3 months

*   **Yes**
    *   Symptom resolution ✓
    *   Continue ATT ✓

*   **No**
    *   **Increase in size of LN ± signs of inflammation**
        *   Check old culture report
        *   Send new cultures if not available
        *   Susceptible TB (5)
            *   Paradoxical worsening (6)
            *   Refer to higher centre
        *   Drug resistant TB (8)
            *   Therapeutic drug monitoring (7) ✓
                *   *Handwritten note:* sometimes drugs might Not reach to the LN properly [Drugs may Not have properly metabolised & reaching LN]
            *   Refer to DOTS plus centre (9)

    *   **Constitutional symptoms persist** (a)
        *   R/o alternate diagnosis (b)
        *   *Handwritten notes:*
            *   ? DRTB ✓
            *   ? Drug related -> TDM ✓
            *   ? Paradoxical worsening ✓
            *   ? Alternate diagnosis ✓

---
BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

# Treatment

⭐ when to stop ATT in patients with persistently enlarged ⭐ mediastinal lymph nodes ?

✓ when there is absence of interval change in CT/MRI of mediastinal lymph nodes for more than 4 months

✓ with a resolution of all other clinical signs and symptoms.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB. FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 24 -->



# Residual lymphadenopathy - at the end of treatment

(Handwritten notes: 6m Rx, >1cm size)

*   **Residual lymphadenopathy > 1cm size**
    *   (Handwritten notes: Inguinal LNs: >2cm? significant, All other LNs: >1cm)
    *   **If clinical features have persisted or reappeared:**
        *   Extend 3m Rx (Handwritten, circled)
        *   Addnl 3 months of RHE
        *   Followed by BIOPSY & culture (Handwritten: sensitivities)
    *   **If clinical features have resolved:**
        *   Residual fibrotic LN
        *   NO NEED TO EXTEND ATT

---
DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FAGI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 25 -->



# Paradoxical Reaction

*   Patient on ATT
*   Initial Improvement
*   Clinical or radiological worsening of pre-existing lesions / new lesions are developed (Handwritten: lesions)
*   first 3 weeks to 4 months may be due- Paradoxical Reaction (Handwritten: worsening due to immune system)

self-limiting, serious morbidity and, on rare occasions, death

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM
45

---

<!-- Page 26 -->



# Paradoxical Reaction

*   Rule out alternative diagnosis

Management:
*   Continuation of ATT
*   Symptomatic treatment
*   NSAIDs for pain
*   USG guided aspiration in fluctuation For biopsy & culture

*Handwritten notes:*
If you are strongly suspecting something else
↓ an ORTB Alternate cause

---

<!-- Page 27 -->



## Follow up
1, 2, 3-4 and 6 months.
Imaging to be repeated if clinically indicated.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

# Treatment ; EVENTS

I. The appearance of new lymphadenopathy during RX or Enlargement of the existing nodes :
* paradoxical response? ✔ → If yes → wait & watch | symptomatic Mxl
* Superadded infection? ✔ [High grade fever, local rise of temperature, fluctuant +ve]
* Nontuberculous mycobacterial infection ?? [Like initially it was AFB +ve & NAAT -ve, But was thought on MTB]
* Alternative diagnosis e.g., malignancy, Kikuchi-Fujimoto, Kimura lymphadenitis Kikuchi-Fujimoto, Kimura lymphadenitis
* Treatment failure or Decreased compliance issues / Poor absorption, Poor drug penetration into the lymph node/absorption
* Drug resistance (INH mono-resistance/MDR TB)
